So people want to write as fast as I can in order to have fluent interaction and chats communication.

We have abbreviations, acronyms, deviations from standard spelling, Anna, lot of expression of emoticons.
So flooding in multi consent selves but also capitalized letters.
And then we also have a couple of Dutch specific phenomena, so we have concatenation of tokens that are very frequent.

This gives a lot of problems for our tax analysis tools because they are trained on standard language and they fail miserably on this user generated content.
So you have two solutions in this case you can make new tools that are trained on social media data.
This is what happens sometimes, but we have opted for the second option and this is to normalize the nonstandard language.
Into its standard variance.

Three dominant approaches have been applied, so you can take a machine translation approach and there you consider the chat language as you would consider a given source language and you try to translate it into a given target language.
Being the standard language.
In this case you can apply spell checking where you do something like you normally do, and you do spell checking, so you look for words that are similar to words in your dictionary with standard.
Language words or you can apply some kind of speech recognition metric where you consider the chat language as being speech that has to be converted into text.
So we mainly choose for statistical machine translation approach.

We have some basic pre processing so tokenization sentence splitting.
We do something with emoticons, emojis and we solve character flooding and then we have a couple of modules that work on the work level.
So we have abbreviation module that just looks at an expansion dictionary for the typical chat abbreviations.
We have a spell checker where we apply a Levenstein distance.
So it means that you look for words that are similar where you do not need too many operations to go to existing words in a dictionary.
We have a compound module that checks if a pair of words should actually be one word, because in Dutch the compounds and chat like, which are often written apart, we have a word splatter.
This is the opposite, so we try to have words that are concatenated, split and towards.
Then we also have a couple of modules that work across the network level, so we have our machine translation module.

User generated content.
So as you all know in social media languages it deviates from standard language.
It has already been brought up.
People of times.
And then you'd already touched upon the the maxims of chat language as well.
So people want to write as fast as I can in order to have fluent interaction and chats communication.
And they also try to write as they speak in order to have this informal character of the conversation going.
And this leads to a couple of properties of chat language, so we have omission of words and characters.
We have abbreviations, acronyms, deviations from standard spelling, Anna, lot of expression of emoticons.
So flooding in multi consent selves but also capitalized letters.
And then we also have a couple of Dutch specific phenomena, so we have concatenation of tokens that are very frequent.
We have elimination of critics and pronouns and we have a lot of dialect, so Flemish is.
Very well known for having a lot of dialectal variation, and people use these dialects lots in chat language.
So this is an example of an original language.

I won't pronounce it because it's not my own dialect, so it has been normalized and as you can see there are lots of normalization operations going on to achieve something that looks like standard touch.
OK, so it's really problematic in that.
The language that is used in chat language, Ann's also already mentioned before.
This gives a lot of problems for our tax analysis tools because they are trained on standard language and they fail miserably on this user generated content.
So you have two solutions in this case you can make new tools that are trained on social media data.
This is what happens sometimes, but we have opted for the second option and this is to normalize the nonstandard language.
Into its standard variance.
However, on the positive sides we also see that a nonstandard language sometimes makes the NLP analysis easier.
For instance, if you have a lot of flooding or expression markers, this can help you to do sentiment analysis, for instance.
So sometimes it's a bit dubious if you want to perform the normalization or not, depending on the task you are.
Forming OK for normalization.

Three dominant approaches have been applied, so you can take a machine translation approach and there you consider the chat language as you would consider a given source language and you try to translate it into a given target language.
Being the standard language.
In this case you can apply spell checking where you do something like you normally do, and you do spell checking, so you look for words that are similar to words in your dictionary with standard.
Language words or you can apply some kind of speech recognition metric where you consider the chat language as being speech that has to be converted into text.
So we mainly choose for statistical machine translation approach.
And we added some other modules as well, so we have an ensemble approach where we have the noisy text coming in.
We do some basic pre processing and correction of flooding.
Then we have a couple of modules.
I will come back to them in the next slides.
We also keep track of the original word because not every word needs to be normalized.
Then we have all these normalization suggestions that come out of the different modules and we have a decision module that results in a normalized.
Version of the text.
OK, So what are the modules?
We have some basic pre processing so tokenization sentence splitting.
We do something with emoticons, emojis and we solve character flooding and then we have a couple of modules that work on the work level.
So we have abbreviation module that just looks at an expansion dictionary for the typical chat abbreviations.
We have a spell checker where we apply a Levenstein distance.
So it means that you look for words that are similar where you do not need too many operations to go to existing words in a dictionary.
We have a compound module that checks if a pair of words should actually be one word, because in Dutch the compounds and chat like, which are often written apart, we have a word splatter.
This is the opposite, so we try to have words that are concatenated, split and towards.
Then we also have a couple of modules that work across the network level, so we have our machine translation module.
We have a transliteration module that is a memory based learning module and there you try to convert a given sequence given a given sequence of this proceeding and following.
So you really look at the context.
For instance, the words need not end, which is often abbreviated in chat language as needed.
So you want to convert that into it given certain words or sequences, either following or preceding.
Then we also have a phonetic module and we also keep track of the original module.
So all these modules give suggestions for normalization and then there is a decision module that has to decide which suggestions are good and therefore we use also the machine translation decoder.
So the Moses decoder to perform.
The picking of the good suggestions.
